TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen the reported comments of the New South Wales Minister for Industrial Relations conceding that the number of claims of unfair dismissal of workers in New South Wales has risen over the past few months? Is this likely to happen under the Federal Government's industrial relations policies? What avenues of redress are available under these policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen remarks by Mr John Hannaford, the Minister for Industrial Relations in New South Wales, that unfair dismissal claims going to the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission are averaging 130 a month. That is pretty typical of what is happening all around Australia. The question of what separates us from the Opposition is how fairly they are being dealt with. We have a system of supports for people who have been unfairly dismissed. Mr Hannaford, to his credit, in New South Wales is talking now about introducing a legal advice centre to help workers in that State where they have been unfairly dismissed.

PARA.TAB: What applies in New South Wales is, unfortunately, typical of what applies everywhere where employment contracts operate. It is certainly typical of New Zealand. The legacy of the Thatcher Government in the United Kingdom is that workers who are unfairly dismissed are thrown upon the common law—law, I might say, that is archaic. In Victoria we now have the spectacle of the Victorian Opposition proposing to dispense with access to the Commission for workers who have been unfairly dismissed. That Opposition's policy provides that a worker will have to pay a $50 filing fee and then prima facie establish an entitlement to be dealt with by the new structure.

If a worker is not dealt with in that way, he or she will have to go to common law, and we all know that common law is a feast for lawyers. The price of justice at law is excessive and beyond the reach of most ordinary people. As far as the Commonwealth is concerned, we will not go down that route. We will maintain the awards management branch of our Department, which helps workers in dire straits such as these.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Government have any plans to reduce the funding of government programs which give workers opportunities to seek a remedy for claims of unfair dismissal? What would be the effect if the budgets of these government programs were cut?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —We have the awards management branch, which helps in these circumstances; we have the Industrial Relations Commission, which we retain and which the Opposition will want to neuter; and we have as well the small claims process proclaimed in the Federal Act on 22 July this year. The Opposition, to its everlasting shame, is proposing to cut these programs. The Fightback package proposes to slash in half the funding for the awards management branch, which means that, if the Opposition were ever in office, a lot of ordinary Australians would be denied access to justice at law because they could not have the necessary support to enable them to contest their cases.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard said that he would stab the Industrial Relations Commission in the stomach. His words were, `I intend to stab them in the stomach'. That is true. As well, if he gets the chance, he will stab in the stomach ordinary Australian workers who have been unfairly dismissed and victimised in their employment. He will do so by cutting the services available to them from the Commonwealth, aimed at helping them to get justice at law. I think that is a shameful circumstance.

If one looks at the Victorian situation, one sees archaic common law in which workers are regarded as servants or as chattels. At that law they have essentially no rights, but they are enjoined to go to that forum to uphold twentieth century rights of entitlement in order to be respected as employees and have entitlements. If one goes to the common law one is dealing with law which has been overtaken by statute law, which is archaic, which is not applicable to a modern society and for which the odds are stacked against one anyway—unless one is wealthy enough to be able to afford lawyers or QCs to match the fire power of companies able to employ high priced silks or high priced lawyers to protect their interests.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the Treasurer's announcement yesterday of the Government's putting more taxes on Australian business and Australian jobs. Can the Minister confirm that the effective rate of fringe benefits tax payable on motor cars provided by employers to employees has nearly doubled? Also, as the incentive to provide motor vehicles in the form of fringe benefits has now been removed, how many of the 190,000 annual fleet sales does the Government expect to be lost?

—There is a lot of misapprehension about this. Today, I heard somebody saying that a commercial traveller's car will be subject to the higher rate of fringe benefits. Some tax consultant replied, `No, that's not right; it's used for business purposes'. Motor vehicles have always been treated concessionally under the FBT. They will continue to be subject to a concessional formula and that is referred to in Mr Dawkins' statement. I am not saying that the motor vehicle industry fleet sales will not be affected but it will still be a concessionally treated fringe benefit. In the next two years companies will have plenty of time to consider this in terms of remuneration packages. The proposals announced yesterday are about introducing further equity and fairness into the tax system; that was the purpose of the fringe benefits change and also the purpose of the new compliance provisions which were introduced. The Minister has confirmed that fleet sales will be slashed under the new tax arrangements, but he has not answered the first part of my question, which is to confirm that the fringe benefits tax on motor cars will be nearly doubled. Is that correct? Can the Minister confirm that the FBT will be doubled on cars?

—I cannot and I will not confirm that. I did not say that fleet sales would be slashed; that is reading things into what I said. I do not expect that to be a result of this at all when people sit down to consider the relative benefits of salary and other remuneration packages as they will have time to do in the next two years.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Does the Government acknowledge that an effective response to the threat of terrorism cannot be achieved by Australia acting alone? What measures are being taken by the Minister to ensure a high level of cooperation with other relevant agencies in our region?

—The fact is that politically motivated violence, terrorism, within Australia is—thank goodness—only very rare in its incidence; but nevertheless, we should not be lulled into a false sense of security. In a conference of regional countries—in north Asia, South East Asia, the Pacific, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka—which opened in Perth on Monday, a concerted effort was made by representatives from those countries to enter into cooperative and collaborative arrangements to ensure that we can all combat terrorism, politically motivated violence, wherever it is threatened or occurs.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy President, you will recall that this Senate actually passed legislation only last week to deal with the sort of situation that arose with the Achille Lauro incident in the Mediterranean, where terrorists were able to escape justice. With the hijacking of that vessel and the killing and throwing overboard, as I recall, of an American citizen, there was no way in which the international community could respond effectively because of a lack of cooperative measures being able to be set in train. That difficulty has been overcome by this Parliament, only last week, by its passing a particular measure. We will be reinforcing that by passing in the next few weeks a law dealing with piracy on the high seas and ensuring that there are very high penalties enforceable in Australian courts in relation to that offence. Not only can this offence cause loss of life in waters to our north; it can also disrupt commercial shipping—for example, through the Malacca Straits—which can have a very severe impact on the commercial and trading life of this region.

With cooperation and collaboration among regional countries, I believe Australia can make a very real contribution to fighting terrorism, whether it occurs within Australia or, as I say, within our region.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Minister seen the statement issued yesterday by the Catholic bishops of Australia? Does he agree with their criticism that the `survival of the fittest' philosophy, which has guided those in power in recent years, is unchristian and directly responsible both for the decay in values and for growing inequity and injustice in Australian society? Does he consider that the tax cuts announced by the Treasurer yesterday are in line with the call for greater equity and fairness made by the Catholic bishops, or with a continuation of economic Darwinism?

—Senator Coulter has asked me to make a number of philosophical assumptions, which I am not prepared to do. I am only a lawyer. I did not see the statement by the Catholic bishops, but I saw Bishop Brennan as I went past a television set last night. I share the general concern and compassion which are expressed in that statement. A lot of the difficulties to which I suspect the bishops were referring have been occasioned by levels of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: We have debated the recession often enough in this place. As we come out of the recession, those things will improve. As compared with many other countries, we have a strong social safety net in this country. Of course, this would be seriously damaged by an alternative government which has to find $10 billion worth of cuts in outlays in order to finance a package based on greed.

The honourable senator asked whether the tax cuts are in line with greater equity and so on. The tax cuts which are available to high income earners, those above $50,000, under the Labor Government are equitable right through. Whether you are on $50,000 or $100,000, you will receive the same amount. In respect of people at the lower end of the income scale, this Government has targeted a whole range of social benefits to assist them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the implications of the Government's decision to help fund an international television service targeted at South East Asian regional centres. Given the decision by the ABC to accept sponsorship for this service, can the Australian people be assured that no sponsorship will be allowed on domestic air services?

—I can give that assurance. I am delighted to advise the Senate—I must say, no more delighted than my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans—that Cabinet last night took a decision to assist the ABC to commence a uniquely Australian broadcasting service into South East Asia.
—That is great.

—Yes, it is great. It is a tremendous initiative in substantially upgrading Australia's presence in one of the most important regions in the world, so far as we are concerned. Darwin will be the major transmission point for this new television service, which is a key element in the Federal Government's strategy of forging closer economic and cultural ties with our northern neighbours.

PARA.TAB: The footprint for the service, which is on the Indonesian Palapa satellite, is very large. It covers the whole of South East Asia—countries such as Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei, the Philippines, Taiwan, Burma, Vietnam, Laos, Thailand, Cambodia, Hong Kong and China. It will be uniquely Australian, broadcasting regional news, current affairs, co-produced specials, series, drama, documentaries, children's programs and so on; and, in the first year, 10 specially commissioned South East Asian documentary programs.

The ABC's decision to allow corporate sponsorship for the service will assist it to buy program material outside its own sources, for example, sport and drama. The overseas service, which will begin later this year, will see the creation of around 20 jobs, the majority to be based in Darwin.

As my colleague the Minister for Tourism pointed out in a subsequent statement, this will provide a significant boost to tourism for Australia by complementing the Australian Tourist Commission's promotions in the same region, which is so vital to our future. TALK.START.PARA: —We do.
—You do; excellent.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Australia having nominated Justice Elizabeth Evatt for membership of the Human Rights Committee, and the elections to this Committee having been held at the meeting of the 110 states party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in New York on 10 September, would Senator Evans please inform the Senate of the results of the election?

—Justice Elizabeth Evatt, President of the Australian Law Reform Commission, was, I am very pleased to report, elected to the Human Rights Committee on 10 September for a four-year term to begin in January of next year. She will be the first Australian member ever elected to that Committee. The Committee, which has 18 members, was established in 1976 as the supervisory body for the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and it is regarded as the most influential international human rights body. The Committee is empowered to consider reports by the states parties on measures adopted and progress made in observance of the various rights set out in the Covenant. It also issues general recommendations interpreting the contents of the Covenant and, in the case of those states parties, like Australia, which have acceded to the first optional protocol to the Covenant, considers communications from individuals who claim that their rights under the Covenant have been violated and have exhausted all domestic remedies.

PARA.TAB: The Committee members are recognised for their competence and experience in the field of human rights and serve as independent experts. Of the 109 states parties which took part in the voting on 10 September, 82 voted for Justice Evatt. This was the most votes received by any of the 19 candidates for the nine vacancies on the Committee. The level of support her candidature received—not only in the vote on that day, but also in the very positive responses to the representations that were made on her behalf by my Department and our missions overseas—was really pretty extraordinary. I think it is fair to say that the result reflects credit not only on Australia's excellent record as a country, and the respect and reputation which we have in human rights matters, but more particularly, on Justice Evatt's own very high personal standing in the international community, not least as a result of her record as one of the most influential members of the UN Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women during the last eight years. That record and her election to the Human Rights Committee bring great credit to Justice Evatt and to Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that because the Ukraine is not designated a developing country, this has resulted in the Aid for Chernobyl Children's Fund experiencing great difficulty attracting donations as it does not have tax deductible status? Secondly, can the Minister explain how funds donated for aid programs operating in countries such as Thailand, which is a country regarded as one of Asia's economic tigers, can be tax deductible whereas funds donated for programs in Russia and the Ukraine, nations in severe decline, are not? Thirdly, would the Minister be prepared to review the tax deductible status for donations to the Aid for Chernobyl Children's Fund and perhaps reassess the classification of the Ukraine as a developing country given its state of economic collapse?

—The Ukraine is not, Senator, as you pointed out, designated as a developing country for the purposes of the Australian tariff system and so on. But this question is more appropriately directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I think he heard the question. Perhaps you would like him to answer it now or provide you with an answer.
—I would like that.

—The situation is this: tax deductibility for aid purposes in Australia depends on my being able to certify, as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, that the country in question is a developing country. The practice has been to treat for this purpose as the definition of `developing country' that adopted by the OECD and the Development Assistance Committee. There has been a long argument going on—for two or three years now—in that committee about whether the countries of eastern Europe, including Ukraine, should be regarded as having developing status. Australia has taken the view that they should not, notwithstanding some obvious arguments that can be put for that status. We believe that to do so would result in a fairly quick and substantial diversion of aid from countries in Africa, Latin America and some parts of Asia, which arguably are in even greater need.

PARA.TAB: The reason for that is that a number of western aid donors are, for a whole variety of reasons, rather keen to channel aid into eastern European countries and would do so if these had the developing country status. The donor countries could then claim it as aid and increase their ratio as a result, or have it counted in the aid to GNP ratio, which is the measure of a country's development assistance performance. We have had very strong representations from just about the whole of the developing world against such a re-characterisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some days ago Senator Reid asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services about a report conducted by Harding and Landt. The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Reid asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, without notice on 10 September 1992:

I refer to the study that the Department had conducted by Harding and Landt which showed that most Australians have suffered a decline in living standards since Labor came into power in 1983. In particular, it showed that a two income family with average weekly earnings and two children suffered a real decline of $1,000 per year, which was 3 per cent. Why has the Government allowed this disastrous situation to continue?

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate—The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the Honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The evidence in the paper by Dr Harding and Mr Landt does not show that general living standards have declined in the period 1983 to 1991. Rather it shows that some groups have had a decline in money incomes but many groups are in fact better off, with the most disadvantaged groups doing best.

PARA.TAB: it shows that the vast majority of social security recipients, after taking full account of inflation, had significantly increased incomes over the period. For example the real disposable income of a full rate pensioner couple rose by 14.1 per cent and for a pensioner couple receiving rent assistance this increase was 18.7 per cent. A sole parent pensioner with two children who was renting privately had a 24.9 per cent increase in income.

such increases have markedly reduced the high poverty rates for sole parents and for pensioner, allowee and beneficiary couples with children that existed when the Labor government came to power in 1983.

ANSWER.PARA: The study does show that most couples with children with incomes around the middle of the income distribution experienced real falls in their disposable income. This has been as a result of the wage restraint which has been in place throughout most of the period and which meant that jobs were created and so many families enjoyed the increase in living standards which went with employment and moving off income support payments.
The Government acknowledges that some people suffered declines in disposable incomes and has put in place policies to correct this.

In doing this it has been necessary to look beyond income when looking at living standards, as acknowledged by the authors of this paper. This Government has taken a multidimensional approach to focus on the various social and economic factors that contribute to Australia's living standards. The Government's policies have, therefore, recognised the importance of addressing concurrently the issues of improving the income support system, improving access to work opportunities and improving the provision and access to services that families need. This Government has worked to maintain living standards by:

PARA.TAB: increasing and indexing social security payments targeted at low income families, particularly through the Family Allowance Supplement and increased additional pension and benefit levels for families with children;
improving access to health services through the introduction of Medicare and improving the standard of and access to aged care services;

linking social security payments to opportunities to enter or re-enter the labour market through programs such as NEWSTART and JET (Jobs, Education and Training), which are of particular benefit to groups such as the long-term unemployed, sole parents and people with disabilities, who have experienced severe disadvantage in finding and retaining work;
alleviating the costs of housing through increased rent assistance payments to low income private tenants, and public housing (through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement);

expanding significantly access to community based child care facilities, changing child care fee relief arrangements to make child care more affordable and extending child care to work-based centres; and

increasing school retention rates by increasing financial incentives for disadvantaged young people to stay at school through AUSTUDY and related programs, thus improving the incentive for young people to attain higher standards of education.

ANSWER.PARA: These measures are the important ones in measuring living standards and cash incomes are only one part of this. When a complete examination of trends in living standards in the period in question is undertaken it will show that Labor presided over a period of improvement rather than decline.

The Government has recently established the Centre of Social and Economic Modelling (COSEM) with Dr Harding as the director to undertake this type of multidimensional analysis which will help formulate policy in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) to a question asked by Senator Aulich on 17 September 1992 relating to the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister, in response to a question from Senator Aulich, referred to an article in the Canberra Times today which was quite clearly and obviously planted there by the Minister. One of the good things about being the shadow Minister for administrative services is that the Minister is Senator Bolkus. He is like one of those ducks in sideshow alley. You hit it with a ball, it falls over, and when it gets up it is ready to be knocked over again. The line that he ran today in the Canberra Times is identical to the line he ran six months ago, and six months before that, which was totally discredited not only by me but by the whole Press Gallery, who ignored it entirely.

PARA.TAB: Let me give the background to why he ran that article. In the Estimates Committee last week I asked the Minister a series of simple questions. One was whether a workshop had been held at Thredbo, one of the good resorts, for senior executives of the Department of Administrative Services, at taxpayers' expense. The answer was yes. I asked why that workshop was held, and I was told, `Because we were reviewing what we did last year and our plans for the future'. I asked whether any aspects of the workshop were devoted to the coalition's Fightback package, and the answer was no.

My response then was: `If that is the case, how do I have in my possession a document entitled "Thredbo workshop, Fightback, Report to the Minister"?'. When I asked who organised it, the final admission was that it was between the Minister and the Secretary. Here we have taxpayers' money being used to send a group of senior executives in the Public Service to a resort to discuss the coalition's Fightback package. That is the background to this matter. It is yet another effort to come up with these phoney figures.

I will touch yet again on where the Minister is amiss. He claims that the savings, as outlined by the coalition, of $220m cannot be met. He then makes the bizarre claim that it will, in fact, cost $1 billion. Let us just analyse that very briefly. When it was first mooted that the saving would be about $220m a year, the Minister came in and said, `You cannot do that'. We used the 1990-91 figures because they were actual figures. As anyone would know, with this Government you cannot use Forward Estimates because they have not been accurate for the last 10 years; they are decidedly rubbery. I am glad we did use 1990-91 figures. On the basis of those figures, we talked about downsizing in the Department so that we could get some of the featherbedding out of it. The Minister's immediate reaction was to come back and say, `You cannot claim those savings; we are going to that ourselves'. In fact, in Estimates the other day he said that the Government had saved some $200m.

Being a responsible Opposition, we have taken the view all the way through that, if the Government does something we approve of, we will support it. That is the view of John Hewson; it is my view, and the view of everyone on this side, and we did support it. The Minister also said that he has cut out 1,700 jobs, and he is right. The Public Sector Union put out a press release yesterday which said that he is going to fire another 2,300. The Minister's actions are costing jobs. Fightback is all about creating jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to respond to Senator Parer but I felt I had to come down to respond to a couple of points he has made. I do not mind being told I have a capacity to bounce back; I think that is quite useful in politics. In respect of the conference at Thredbo, let me assure Senator Parer that there was no snow at the time. It was the wrong time of the year; it was off-season.
—There is a golf course.

—I do not know whether there is. I drove there very late at night and left mid-afternoon the next day. The conference was held there for a specific purpose: reviewing progress and defining directions into the future. It was held amongst senior officers of a department that has gone through radical change over recent years. In fact, Coopers and Lybrand has produced a report, the details of which were given last week in the Estimates Committee hearing, which indicates that the rate of productivity increase in the Department of Administrative Services has been some 5.6 per cent over recent years, as opposed to half that in the public sector, in general, and as opposed to some quarter of that in the private sector. The people involved in the meeting at Thredbo have been basically presiding over, and riding and driving, enormous change in a government department.

PARA.TAB: Also, as was evidenced last week, the Fightback analysis, which was circulated with other documents, was not on the agenda for discussion. Senator Parer knew that. However, it did not stop him from coming in here and claiming that we had a conference at Thredbo to discuss Fightback. We had better things to do with our time then and we have better things to do with our time now.

Let us go to the substantive point—the analysis of Fightback. It was rather interesting, actually. Senator Lewis was at the Estimates Committee hearing last week. As people would know, we had a whole army of officers there ready to answer questions and they were quite prepared to do so. I was asked whether I had looked at Fightback and whether I had found anything useful in Fightback. I said that I had had a close look at it and that the Department had had a close look at it. There was no idea that we picked up in total. There was one idea that we worked on and that was, of course, the financing of FLEET.

Senator Lewis was, I suppose, slow enough to ask all those officers whether any one of them found anything useful in Fightback. I warned him at the time. I said, `If you get the answer no, you will be really embarrassed'. To that question, I must say that not one person in the room put a hand up and said, `Yes, I found a gem' or, `I found a beauty'—not one person. The basic difference between the Government's approach to this area and the Opposition's is that we have actually commercialised. We have brought in competition and we have entrenched it to the extent that 75 per cent of services now provided by the Department are on a competitive basis. By 1 July next year that will go to 90 per cent. We have done that. We have reduced by 30 per cent or more the level of staffing in the Department. Does the honourable senator support that?

TALK.START.PARA: —We have supported that.

—He has supported it. We have done that through natural attrition and through voluntary retrenchments. Not one person has been sacked by the Department. It is a process that continues and will continue. We recognise that there will have to be greater resource savings and staff savings, and that will continue. They have all been factored in. Those sorts of things are all in the Forward Estimates; they have been factored in. The basic thing is that we have reduced the cost on the Budget by some $200m a year over recent years. That will continue and increase. Those costs and those savings have been factored in by Government by decisions already taken. (Time expired)

—I would not normally get involved in this part of the debate but I wanted to comment on Senator Parer's holier-than-thou attitude to the use of taxpayers' money by a Government Minister to explore, assess and make estimates of costs and effects of Fightback. I found it an exercise in stunning hypocrisy. Like everybody around here, I have been an avid viewer, via the in-house monitor, of the Estimates process. Dozens and dozens of times I have heard Opposition members ask public servants to investigate aspects of the Fightback package. I assume those government employees will be paid by taxpayers' money in doing so. I am not necessarily criticising that as a process, but if it is good enough for Opposition senators as part of the Estimates process to engage in that exercise, then I do not really see any valid basis for Senator Parer's criticism of the process if it is undertaken via a Minister.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in response to a question asked by Senator Michael Baume on 16 September 1992 relating to ministerial disclosure of interests.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, I noted the refusal by Senator Button to indicate that the Government would consider changing the rules to force Mr Keating to come clean on the real nature of his $4.2m equity in his piggery group, all the details of which have emerged only because of my detailed and lengthy searches of company records, which the group was extraordinarily reluctant to lodge with the Australian Securities Commission.

PARA.TAB: I have raised this matter of the incredible delays many times in this chamber.We now know why those delays took place. Many reports from the group are still outstanding in a clear flouting of the ASC's legal requirements. The key point is, though, that Mr Keating simply cannot distance himself from what his half-owned companies do. Yet this basically was his response last night to my comments in the Senate. He tried to distance himself by saying, once again, that he has no links with these companies themselves. He was purporting not to be related to them, although he half-owns them and he has a nominee as a director.

Instead of dealing with the substance of what I said last night, he limited himself, naturally, to personal abuse. It is really significant. He refused to deal at all with the facts eventually revealed by the Keating companies through the Securities Commission. He did not even try to explain the $1.5m profit shuffle when one of his half-owned companies in the group appears to have earned a profit of $1.5m at the cost of another half-owned company in the group. As my press release said last night, not only has he decided not to deal in any way with the substance of what I raised yesterday, he chose, in fact, to try to attack Dr Hewson through me.

TALK.START.PARA: —His answer to everything is to attack Dr Hewson.

—That is his answer to everything. Mr Keating has no policies, no responses to anything, no criticisms of substance. All he can do is personally criticise Dr Hewson. I want to state here, with great vigour: firstly, I stand by all the facts I revealed yesterday, as eventually revealed by the ASC; secondly, I have been pursuing my inquiries into Mr Keating's piggery investment for months, on my own initiative. Not only were my comments and questions yesterday not on Dr Hewson's instructions, but he was totally unaware of them. I suggest that Mr Keating might like to start addressing the substance of these matters, which are very significant indeed.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating may also like to address the incredible situation that Rincraft Pty Ltd—one of his half-owned companies in his piggery group—has net tangible assets of only $175,000 but has been able to borrow $24.8m under the terms of an equitable mortgage from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which has a floating charge over all of its assets. How is it possible that the Keating piggery group has been able to borrow so hugely, at a time when so many farmers are having enormous difficulties getting banks to tide them over in the present economic disaster under this disastrous Keating Government? Perhaps they should all change their names to Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that changes proposed in the recent Budget will mean that many thousands of pensioners will face reductions in pension income because of unrealised capital gains on their hard earned investments. In these circumstances I would have thought that those pensioners were entitled to ask why they should suffer, when someone who paid $430,000 for an interest in a piggery in May last year—which is worth some $4.2m six weeks later—appears to escape scot-free.

PARA.TAB: The Catholic bishops yesterday expressed great concern about wealth disparity in Australia. Cardinal Clancy made a particular point of acknowledging that it is not a crime to be wealthy. There are indeed many generous philanthropists. But I think the essential point is that the community must have confidence in the decision makers, is entitled to know the source of their wealth, and is entitled to know how it comes about that someone can have the capacity to put $400,000-odd into an investment when people in Parliament in most instances are struggling to make ends meet. How on earth can one multiply that by 10 within six weeks? That is a very important public policy issue, which has been totally ignored. I am appalled at the ferocity of Mr Keating's attack on Senator Baume. He displays acute sensitivity and manic determination to intimidate and possibly crucify anyone who disagrees with him. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

This Bill represents a further step towards the rationalisation of the institutional arrangements for the coal mining industry.

The Bill provides for amendments to the Coal Industry Act 1946 and the Industrial Relations Act 1988 in order to transfer the function of providing administrative support for the Coal Industry Tribunal from the Joint Coal Board to the Australian Industrial Registry. The Bill also amends the audit provisions of the Coal Industry Act 1946 to bring the audit arrangements for the Joint Coal Board into line with current practice.
The New South Wales Government has undertaken to make complementary amendments to the Coal Industry Act 1946 of New South Wales.

The amendments concerning administrative support for the Tribunal are concerned solely with that subject and do not in any way alter the Tribunal's industrial relations powers and functions. Some coal mining industry parties have put it to me that they would like to see changes made to those powers and functions. It has become apparent in the course of discussions I have already had with the parties that there is a range of strongly held and widely divergent views about that. Any change to the Tribunal's powers and functions will only be made after full consultation and discussion with all parties. I have commenced that process of consultation.

At present, the Coal Industry Act 1946 establishes that the Joint Coal Board is responsible for providing administrative assistance to the Tribunal. The Board employs the staff who provide that assistance. The Tribunal is funded, through the Joint Coal Board, on a 50/50 basis by the Commonwealth and New South Wales Governments.

Recent amendments to the Coal Industry Act 1946 of the Commonwealth and the Coal Industry Act 1946 of New South Wales have redefined the role of the Board by providing that it will in future focus on workers' compensation and miners' health and welfare, and that it will become self financing.

It is inconsistent with this redefined role that the Board should continue to provide administrative support for the CIT. This Bill amends the Industrial Relations Act 1988 and the Coal Industry Act 1946 so that the Australian Industrial Registry will be responsible for providing administrative support for the Tribunal. This will include the provision of administrative staff.
In making these administrative changes, it is not the intention of the Government to alter the level of administrative support provided to the Tribunal.
The New South Wales Government will continue to make its contribution to the funding of the Tribunal under the new arrangements.
The amendments concerning the audit provisions specify the matters which must be incorporated in the Joint Coal Board's Annual Report, including its financial statements.

The Board will be required to submit its financial statements to the Auditor-General for report to Ministers before submitting its Annual Report to the Commonwealth Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the State Minister for tabling in the Commonwealth and New South Wales Parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL 1992
The Social Security Amendment Bill 1992 gives effect to changes in the area of Education Leavers Waiting Periods.

This Bill modifies the Education Leavers Waiting Period provisions in the Social Security Act 1991 applicable to education leavers who claim Job Search Allowance or Sickness Allowance. These waiting periods are required to be served before a person can become eligible for those payments from the Department of Social Security.

There has been some concern that young people leaving school must normally serve a 13 week waiting period (or 6 weeks if they are over 21, are partnered or have a dependant child) from the date of claiming income support, the day after they cease studies or the date of registration with the CES (depending on the date of claim). Some ex-students might be disadvantaged if they fail to claim income support as soon as they should, perhaps because they are unaware of available assistance or because they are unsure of their future education plans. The amendments in the Bill will ensure that people claiming Job Search Allowance or Sickness Allowance who have recently left secondary education would be eligible for payment 13 or 6 weeks (whichever period is applicable to the person) from the date of leaving education or from 15 February in the following year, whichever is the earlier.

It is considered that the current Education Leavers Waiting Period provisions should also be modified in relation to people who undertake longer term education. Under current arrangements, those who undertake courses of six months or longer face a waiting period if they need to return to DSS income support at the end of the course. The second amendment I propose will waive the waiting period for those who return to income support within 12 months of leaving it. The Government is anxious to encourage young people, particularly secondary school students, to remain in education. This initiative is consistent with that objective.

Under current arrangements, those subject to the waiting period can have only full-time employment taken into account in the assessment of a reduction in the waiting period. For each full-time week of work, the waiting period is reduced by a week. It is recognised that young people have reduced opportunities for full-time work especially under current economic conditions. The third element of this package of measures addresses this problem by reducing the waiting period for periods of paid part-time and/or casual work. If the amount of part-time and/or casual work amounts to 35 hours (regarded as one week's full-time work) the employment would be taken into account in reducing the waiting period by one week. If more than 35 hours is worked a further pro-rata reduction in the waiting period will be allowed. If the amount of part-time and casual work amounts to less than 35 hours then the waiting period would not be reduced. It is considered that this initiative will remove any perceived disincentives and encourage young school leavers to test their workforce potential by taking up casual and part-time opportunities.

The last element of the waiting period measures affects hardship cases. At present special benefit may be paid in a deferment period to young people in hardship. This involves, among other things, an application and grant for Special Benefit and a subsequent transfer to another payment at the end of the waiting period. The amendment in this Bill would effectively waive the waiting period in such cases. If the young person qualified for Special Benefit in what would otherwise be a waiting period, the waiting period would not apply and the primary allowance would be paid.
These Education Leavers Waiting Period measures will come into effect on 2 November 1992.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992
The Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 will give effect to a change in the payment arrangements for Family Allowance. Family Allowance will be called Family Payment from 1 January 1993.

PARA.TAB: Following the outstanding success of the Family Allowance bonus paid earlier this year the Government has decided that payments of Family Allowance should be more flexible. The Family Allowance proposal contained in this Bill will enable recipients of that payment as at 1 January next year to request an advance of the payment covering a period of up to six months. The person requesting the advance would be able to receive up to half of the amount that would be paid in respect of what is known as the "first child rate" ($20.90 per fortnight as from 1 January 1993) as a lump sum. The remaining half of the Family Allowance entitlement would continue to be paid fortnightly. The advance is not to be paid in respect of a particular child, rather as an advance of an amount otherwise payable to a family in receipt of Family Allowance. One advance only would be allowed for each six month period.

If a request for the advance was received, say, in December this year, the person would be able to receive 6 months of half of the Family Allowance first child rate that would have been paid up to 30 June 1993, which will be valued next year at $135.85. At the time of the request the person can opt to have the lump sum advance paid only in respect of the following six months period or on an ongoing basis. If the ongoing option were chosen the person could still contact the Department of Social Security at any time to resume full fortnightly payments which would then recommence at the beginning of the next six months Family Payment advance period.
This new system of advance payment of Family Allowance recognises that some families may wish to receive Family Allowance payments in a lump sum to assist, for example, in family budgeting.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: DEVELOPMENT ALLOWANCE AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill amends the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 (the Principal Act).

The primary purpose of the Bill is to amend the Principal Act to increase the flexibility of the legislation so that a more consistent approach is available to the various types of prospective applicant for the development allowance.

Where all other criteria in the Principal Act are met, these amendments would allow, firstly, applicants to elect to aggregate projects consisting of the establishment of new productive facilities with other projects consisting of the expansion, improvement or upgrading of existing productive facilities where the new and existing productive facilities are vertically integrated.

Secondly, the amendments would allow a project to qualify where the project involves both leased and purchased assets and either or both enable the project to meet the $50 million qualifying threshold.

Thirdly, the amendments permit a lessor to obtain the development allowance in respect of plant which is subject to a long term lease and has been certified for pre-qualification by the DAA on application by the lessee, even if only part of the plant covered by the relevant project is leased.
These amendments provide additional flexibility for claiming the development allowance benefit and in particular, in passing the $50 million threshold.

The opportunity is also taken to make minor adjustments to the drafting of certain provisions in the Principal Act to facilitate interpretation by applicants for the allowance, and to make some minor administrative adjustments.
I now turn to a more detailed discussion of these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Project Definition

PARA.TAB: This Bill expands the concepts of project schemes in the Principal Act to allow the aggregation of new productive facilities with the expansion, improvement or upgrading of existing productive facilities. This is achieved by introducing two new types of scheme, an "individual project scheme" and a "joint venture project scheme". These schemes allow projects involving new productive facilities to be added to projects involving for example the expansion of existing productive facilities to qualify overall for the development allowance and, in particular, to meet the $50 million threshold test. Projects in such schemes must meet the vertical integration test.

SPEECH.PARA: Leased Plant

PARA.TAB: While the Principal Act provides for leased plant to be eligible for the development allowance, it does not permit a combination of purchased and leased assets used in a project to be aggregated for the purpose of meeting the $50 million threshold test. The Bill expands the definitions of plant expenditure and gross capital expenditure to give applicants more flexibility in structuring their projects.
This Bill also introduces a mechanism by which a lessor can claim the development allowance benefit by way of a pre-qualifying certificate that has been issued by the DAA to the lessee.

SPEECH.PARA: Consequential Adjustments

PARA.TAB: As a result of the amendments involving single entity project schemes, joint venture project schemes, and projects involving a mixture of acquired and leased assets, a number of consequential changes to other parts of the Act have been necessary, in particular to the "competitiveness test", and the "$50 million threshold test". In addition, consequent upon the amendments allowing a mixture of purchased and leased plant, this Bill permits proposals to incur plant expenditure to count even if the entity has not decided at the relevant time whether to acquire, construct or lease the plant.

SPEECH.PARA: The Vertical Integration Test

PARA.TAB: The vertical integration test for company group project schemes contained in subsection 14(2) of the Principal Act has been simplified to avoid confusion. The amendment also clarifies that company group project schemes may consist of both new productive facilities and the expansion, upgrade or improvement of existing productive facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: "Australia

PARA.TAB: A definition of "Australia" is introduced to ensure that the original intention of having its meaning consistent between the Principal Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 is achieved. This amendment will, for example, enable certain off-shore oil and gas projects to qualify for the development allowance (provided, of course, that such projects meet the other tests in the Principal Act).

SPEECH.PARA: Typographical Correction

PARA.TAB: A typographical error in paragraph 9(b) of the Principal Act is corrected to clarify that this paragraph refers to "goods and related goods" rather than "goods and related services".

SPEECH.PARA: Certified Copies of Documents

PARA.TAB: There is also a minor administrative amendment to include a provision to allow the DAA to certify that a copy of a document is in fact a copy of an original document issued by the DAA and to provide that such a certified copy be recognised in courts and tribunals.

SPEECH.PARA: Commencement of the Amendments

PARA.TAB: The amendments, which are either favourable to prospective applicants for the allowance or neutral in character are intended to apply from the date of commencement of the Principal Act—other than the new provision relating to the provision of certified copies of documents, which would apply from the date of Royal Assent to the amending Act.
The amendments do not affect the requirement that applications for the allowance be lodged by 31 December 1992.

The Treasurer has discussed these proposed amendments with Mr Halton, the Development Allowance Authority, who has advised that the Authority will receive applications on the assumption that these proposed amendments will become law, but decisions depending on them will of course have to await their passage through Parliament.

PARA.EMPHASIS: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL BILL 1992

SPEECH.PARA: The National Health and Medical Research Council is Australia's peak advisory body on public health, health care, health and medical research and health ethics.

The Council is one of Australia's great public institutions with a long history. In 1926, following the report of a Royal Commission on Health, a Federal Health Council was established to promote co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States on matters of health.

The National Health and Medical Research Council was established in 1936 by Executive Order and replaced the Federal Health Council. The functions of the first Council, as described by Billy Hughes in his opening address in 1937, were `to promote the health of the people of Australia, to protect them from disease; and to advise, co-ordinate and direct research into the cause of, and cure for those diseases, which levy so heavy a toll upon the community, and which have hitherto baffled medical science.'
While in essence the functions of Council have changed little, they have been refined over time to reflect the changing nature of the health issues facing Australia.

Since its inception in 1936, the advice of the NHMRC has been treated with the highest regard, and a situation exists today where its recommendations and guidelines are adopted nearly automatically in a range of public health areas and it plays a highly influential role in advising on health care practice matters. For example, recently, the NHMRC has provided guidance on matters as diverse as drugs and poisons, child health, communicable diseases, environmental health, ethics, medical and nursing practices, radiation, women's health, public health and psychiatry.

In 1937, Billy Hughes noted that the NHMRC is `national in the broadest sense,' and indeed this remains the case. The States have a high degree of interest and involvement in the Council's public health functions, and NHMRC recommendations are often adopted in State law.

In these circumstances, it becomes increasingly anomalous that the Council is not established by legislation. There can be little doubt that if we were creating such a body today, it would be set up by legislation in the Parliament—to clearly establish its role, its independence and its accountability. During 1990, when the Council was undertaking its regular triennial review, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services had the question of legislation examined and was convinced that the anomalous position of the Council, where it could have been abolished by any Government of the day at the stroke of a pen, needed to be remedied.
The National Health and Medical Research Council should be a creation of the Parliament of Australia, not simply of the executive government.

This Bill will provide the NHMRC with a level of power and accountability in keeping with the status it has now achieved. The Council deals with issues that are of direct concern to all Australians in one way or another—from the food we eat to the air we breathe. These issues should continue to be dealt with expertly and impartially and all citizens should be comfortable in the knowledge that the peak body for advising on these matters is beyond interference. Only statutory independence can assure that degree of comfort and confidence for the community.
Of equal importance, the community is entitled to be confident that such a vital body will operate in a public and open manner and be accountable for its actions.
The legislation will enshrine the independence of the Council and define its relationship with the Parliament and the Minister and with the States and Territories.

The Bill details the role NHMRC will play in advising the Commonwealth and State Governments and the Australian community on health and medical research, public health, health care and health ethics. The principal functions given to the Council in the Bill are:

PARA.TAB: (a) to inquire into, to advise and issue guidelines and to make recommendations on the improvement of health; and the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of disease; the provision of health care; public health research and medical research; and ethical issues relating to health; and
(b) to make recommendations to the Commonwealth on expenditure on public health research and medical research.

SPEECH.PARA: The composition of NHMRC is covered in the Bill. Over the years, in keeping with the changing nature of community interest, and expectations of participation, in health matters, the Council and its committees have been expanded beyond solely an expert group. That health was too important to be left entirely to the professions was recognised at the time of the creation of the Council as its membership then included `an eminent layman and laywoman.'

Included on Council as defined in the Bill are members with stipulated backgrounds and knowledge in the fields of medical standards and post-graduate medical training; health care training; the medical profession; the nursing profession; the trade union movement; business; consumer issues; social welfare services; and environment issues. Also included are representatives from each State or Territory, and a nominee of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The wide range of professions and expertise on Council reflects what the community sees as being of importance in health and medical issues. Further, no appointment to the Council can be made without adherence to consultative arrangements detailed in the Bill. The Minister is required to call for nominees from appropriate peak bodies or organisations, the nature of which is to be in keeping with the background and knowledge expected of the appointee.

Until 1988, the Council was chaired by the Secretary to the Commonwealth Department. Since that time, independent chairs have been appointed—first Professor John Chalmers and at present Dr Diana Horvath. I expect that this new tradition of having independent and highly distinguished chairs will continue.

While the Bill allows for the Minister to give general directions to the Council and to refer matters to it, the Minister is expressly prevented from directing the Council in its allocation of research funding to particular persons or organisations or from directing it on scientific, technical or ethical issues. The Council has an unfettered power to publish reports on matters within its functions.

The Bill also requires the NHMRC to prepare a triennial strategic plan in consultation with the Minister, for tabling in Parliament. The strategic plan sets out the Council's assessment of the major national health issues and describes how it proposes to perform its functions in dealing with those issues. The plan will also include a strategy for health and medical research. I hope that the occasion of tabling the Council's strategic plan each three years will enable the Parliament to have an informed debate on health in Australia.

Much of the work of the Council is first carried out within its principal committees. The Bill allows for the creation of principal committees by the Minister on the advice of the Council and it preserves for the present the existing principal committees: the Public Health Committee; the Health Care Committee; the Medical Research and Public Health Research and Development Committees and the Australian Health Ethics Committee.

Increasingly over recent years, the Council has been opening up its processes and procedures to public participation. For example, the twice yearly sessions of the Council are open to the media. The Bill states the intention of the Parliament that the Council, as far as practicable, adopt a policy of public consultation in relation to matters being considered by it.

In addition, the Bill details a comprehensive consultative process for the Council to abide by when it is considering the issuing of guidelines or the making of recommendations on matters which will be implemented in State legislation. This process of public consultation reflects the highly authoritative nature of the Council's work in such areas. It will first be required to publish the fact that it is proposing to issue guidelines or make regulatory recommendations and to seek submissions and then to publish and seek comment on the draft guidelines or recommendations. The Council must produce and publish procedures to assist persons or bodies to present submissions regarding proposed recommendations or guidelines.

This approach to public consultation reflects the advice of the Administrative Review Council which examined the work of the NHMRC in 1990. It is also consistent with the present practice of the Council.

Also arising from the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council, the Bill prescribes that a position of Commissioner of Complaints is to be established to consider grievances relating to the disbursement of medical and health research grants. The Commissioner will not be reviewing cases on their scientific merits—it will always be the case that some good science will not be able to be funded. Rather the Commissioner will examine the process adopted to see if any fault of process resulted in the aggrieved decision. I do not expect the Commissioner to be a particularly busy position—at present there are only a few complaints a year and these are usually well dealt with by the research committees of the Council. Nevertheless, the position of Commissioner will be a guarantee of the fairness and integrity of the system.

The Bill details the relationship between the NHMRC and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. The Bill provides for the staff and running costs of NHMRC to be provided by arrangement between the chair of Council and the Secretary to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Although the NHMRC will become a statutory authority, there will be no implications for its administrative and secretariat staff. The NHMRC will continue to rely on the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services for its staffing support.
The Bill also includes arrangements for funding research, and in doing so replaces the provisions of the Medical Research Endowment Act 1937, which is to be repealed.

Establishing the NHMRC as a statutory body is, of itself, cost-neutral. Any additional minor expenditure arising from the formal operations of the public consultative functions and the operations of the Commissioner will be absorbed within existing budget levels.

The National Health and Medical Research Council is a vital working asset for the Australian people and one of the most effective examples of working federalism. It has relied on, and will continue to rely on, the efforts of a great many dedicated and professional men and women who bring an astonishing array of expertise and background to the Council and its committees. Australia derives great benefits from their services—given for very little personal return. I believe that this Bill at last recognises their efforts by putting the Council in its right place—as a creation of the Parliament of Australia.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Women's Refuges and Associated Domestic Violence Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my six years in this place—it was six years yesterday—I have risen to speak on the adjournment no more than two or three times. I do so today because I have had brought before me a matter of great concern to me and a matter, I believe, of some urgency. It relates to the Women's Refuges and Associated Domestic Violence Services in my home State of Victoria. Victorian refuges are funded as part of the supported assistance accommodation program, or SAAP, which is a joint Commonwealth-State initiative, and thus this issue is of relevance to us here in the Federal Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Members of the Victorian Women's Refuges and Associated Domestic Violence Services visited my office in Melbourne last week, expressing deep concern about the future of refuges in Victoria. At present in Victoria and, I have no doubt, in all other States the number of refuges and places in those refuges falls far short of the real and, regrettably, increasing needs. The women who visited me were expressing deep concern in particular about the fate of refuges and the associated services should a Kennett coalition government be elected in Victoria on 3 October.

No policy has been announced, but cuts in many community services have been foreshadowed and there are strong rumours about draconian cuts in the refuges area specifically. Perhaps even worse, members of the Liberal and National parties in the Victorian Parliament have been refusing to see delegations wanting to provide information on the refuge movement and to put their case, with the exception of the shadow Attorney-General, Mrs Jan Wade.

It is vital that politicians and other decision makers become aware of the crucial role of refuges and their support services. To that end, I seek leave to incorporate an information document in Hansard which I urge all honourable senators and other parliamentary colleagues, State and Federal, to read and to follow up.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: INFORMATION ABOUT WOMEN'S REFUGES AND ASSOCIATED DOMESTIC VIOLENCE SERVICES

SPEECH.PARA: BY DEFINITION, "a victim of Domestic Violence is an individual who, at the hands of a partner, has suffered persistent verbal, economic, social, sexual or physical abuse which has sustained emotional and/or psychological effects.

Major studies of Domestic Violence have indicated that this individual is much more likely to be female than male. In fact from a mid-80's paper entitled "Police Response To Domestic Violence" we see that 75% of murdered women are killed by a husband or partner. Family violence has not decreased and a woman is far more likely to be a victim of serious assault in her own home than anywhere else.

Quite obviously, the children involved in these situations are equally affected but in a manner over which they have no control. These effects are long term and can result in learned behaviour which can perpetuate the violence from the point of view of both inappropriate submission or domination.

Research shows that women and children in these situations go through a number of "stages of fear", each stage increasing the domination and reducing their self-esteem to the point where it requires considerable effort and a great deal of courage to leave. When such a decision is taken it is imperative that they have a safe and neutral place with informed support in which to consider their options.
HISTORY OF REFUGES.

It was the prevalence of situations such as those above that led to the establishment of womens refuges in the mid-1970's. Brenda House has operated in this field since 1978 and has been able to assist many families to explore their options and determine new directions. Principally, the purpose of a refuge is to provide support and short-term accommodation for single women and women with children from critical domestic violence situations. Often, it is not a good idea for these people to move in with family or friends, however supportive, as in many cases this only compounds the problem and widens the circle of abuse. A refuge provides a neutral point where the woman concerned can try to be objective about her situation and that of her family.

Many refuges were set up independently from a variety of directions to meet these needs in their own communities. Since that time refuges have grouped together under one funding umbrella and with the support of both political parties have formed a statewide network to support women and children in family trauma. We are currently funded as part of the Supported Assistance Accommodation Program (SAAP) which is a Commonwealth/State initiative and look forward to future well informed support from the next Government.
FINDING A REFUGE

Women escaping from violence and requiring refuge support can telephone the Womens Refuge Referral Service which has a number listed in the emergency pages—329 8433. Refuge Referrals keep a record of room available in refuges and the criteria for entry—basically, women must be escaping an abusive partner and have need of the high security of address offered by refuges. They are not able to be accommodated in areas which are considered "unsafe" (i.e. areas near their home, relatives or workplaces) and are best supported when the fear of being followed and further abused is decreased. Such fear is incredibly debilitating and can lessen the ability to consider options rationally to the benefit of all. Refuge Referrals accept calls from women with a wide variety of concerns including family violence, the law, housing, health and others. They are a service that will speak to each woman as needed, offer them information and options and allow them to make up their own minds—it is often critical to positive outcomes that a woman really "owns" the decision to leave. If the woman decides to leave Refuge Referrals will attempt to find refuge or at least temporary emergency accommodation. As the public contact point for refuges they also take calls from and liaise with Police, social workers, community workers etc. The task of Refuge Referrals is becoming increasingly difficult with family violence on the increase and women staying in refuge longer due to the shortage of public and affordable private rental.
TYPE OF SUPPORT REQUIRED AND OFFERED

Refuges can be found in ordinary suburban homes where children can attend our supportive local schools and kindergartens. Our property has four bedrooms and can accommodate up to 18 people. Families have their own bedrooms and share the care of the common areas. They are encouraged to treat the refuge as just that—an escape from danger with space to think, re-establish links with their children and the opportunity to consider options for a stable future. Refuge workers are on the premises from 9-5 to listen, provide information and support and accompany women to doctors, Social Security, CES, solicitors, courts and housing options. We encourage renewed trust in the children, are aware of and provide for their emotional and physical needs, provide cultural support to the many ethnic residents, encourage independence of spirit and emotional support to increase self-esteem. After hours workers rotate to carry an emergency pager and respond to crises. Most women come to refuge with no financial resources. We are able to provide them with basic food and, where necessary, clothing during their time in refuge. Refuge workers are not in the business of breaking up partnerships. Domestic Violence is a criminal act and workers strive to assist women and children involved to the best possible outcomes within the bounds of personal wishes and legal and wider community parameters.
REFUGES AS A STATEWIDE SERVICE/ SECURITY OF ADDRESS

As stated previously and for their safety, it is aimed to physically and geographically separate women and children from their violent situations as much as possible. Thus women within your area and electorate will be best served and protected by refuges in other areas. Recognition of the refuge program as a statewide network is essential to the ongoing success of the program and the best provision of service to our service users. This must be viewed in conjunction with and as complimentary to our associated services who can operate regionally. Thus, we urgently request your support for the statewide nature of our service and for the continued security of address i.e. the address of high security refuges is not made public. The security of address of refuge services has had advantages and disadvantages. The main and most obvious advantage is the safety of the families we support and the safety of the workers. This is absolutely paramount as many partners are violent to the point where they will pull many strings to find their families in retaliation following family crises—women have been killed in other states where this security is not provided. A disadvantage of security of address is the fact that the public is not aware of the real need and purposes of refuge and the level of success of improving quality of life for these families. It is this lack of knowledge that we are currently trying to address
ASSOCIATED SERVICES WITHIN THE DOMESTIC VIOLENCE NETWORK

In the 1980's a number of associated services were initiated by the refuge movement and the challenge undertaken by the government of the day. These services are funded with refuges under the SAAP program. We have welcomed the support of all levels of government in both parties and are currently striving to meet the needs of our funding body (CSV) in these difficult times as well as providing on-going support to women and children affected by Domestic Violence. The associated services mentioned were developed to meet specific needs as follows and are a vital part of the whole program.
REFUGE ETHNIC WORKERS PROGRAM (REWP)

These workers speak a wide variety of languages and will work with non-English speaking residents at their request. They provide cultural support, assist with solicitors, doctors, court etc and with daily concerns within the refuge.
DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND INCEST RESOURCE CENTRE (DVIRC)
This was established to provide a central resource centre for victims of and workers with Domestic Violence. It is a central point for resource sharing among refuges.
WOMEN IN SUPPORTED HOUSING (WISH)
This was aimed at developing housing and other support options for women experiencing Domestic Violence and other personal crises.
OUTREACH SERVICES

The umbrella of Domestic Violence support was increased with the introduction of outreach services in the late 1980's. These services were submitted for and associated with existing refuges. Workers in these services have a public address and actually work with women and children in difficult situations in their own homes but not with the same need of escape. The introduction of Intervention Orders has given women such as these added protection but does not provide for all situations. These orders are easily abused and do not recognise family violence as a criminal act. Should the need arise to escape outreach workers will seek refuge support. Possible situations such as these also emphasise the need for two-worker outreach services for their workers' protection. Refuge services, outreach services and resource centres all meet different needs within the overall framework of Domestic Violence and liaise with each other for the benefit of the program and its users.
STATISTICS DEMONSTRATING CURRENT PROVISION OF REFUGE.

Data recently provided by Refuge Referrals demonstrates that the need for Domestic Violence services is ever-increasing and must be sustained. It is a sad indictment on our society that times of economic crisis show a real increase in family violence. In 1991, Refuge Referrals received 4128 requests for accommodation. 2789 of these calls were requests for refuge accommodation. Of these, 524 women were able to be accommodated mainly in metropolitan services. In addition to this country refuges may also take referrals from other rural services. A high percentage of women accommodated were families of ethnic origin also requiring cultural support. Recent statistics demonstrate the numbers of women placed and not placed 1984-1991. In 1984, 50 per cent of women requesting refuge were placed. In 1991 the families placed had reduced to 15 per cent. These figures reflect two aspects: (a) community education has raised awareness of Domestic Violence and more women are requesting support and (b) the reasons for not placing a family are varied—mainly the refuges are full, other families do no have the need of security of address and are more suited to Outreach intervention and others are simply too scared to leave. It must also be recognised that shortage of affordable housing keeps families in refuge longer and so reduces the numbers supported.
COMMUNITY EDUCATION AND AWARENESS

Our vision for the future for the decrease of Domestic Violence lies with Community Education on all fronts—the Police, community and health workers, legal entities, general public and most important, the children. As women pass through the Domestic Violence network they become more aware of what can be considered acceptable behaviour and what they will tolerate. However it is in the ongoing education of the next generation that important differences can be made. We are funded as Community Development Workers and we are striving to support the women and children who so desperately need refuge and at the same time networking with the community, particularly the schools. We have had a very positive response to a number of talks given to date and will aim to increase our profile in the future to provide avenues for positive interaction.
Thank you again for your time, your understanding and, we trust, your support for the continuing fight against family violence and for the ongoing provision of refuge funds.
BRENDA HOUSE COLLECTIVE
AS A MEMBER OF V.W.R.A.D.V.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document was provided to me by the Brenda House Collective, as a member of the Victorian Women's Refuges and Associated Domestic Violence Services. Victoria is, in fact, the last State in this country where the security of the address of refuges is still maintained. This security is vital to the effective working of, and the safety offered by, refuges to women and children under threat of, or having suffered, domestic violence.

PARA.TAB: That very security makes it very difficult to inform the public, and especially politicians and bureaucrats, of the work and role of refuges. I certainly share the concern of the women who visited me and of all women in the refuge movement around the country about the fate of their refuges and associated services, particularly in Victoria should a coalition government be elected. I do hope that, by providing the information as I have done here today, I have made a contribution to a wider understanding by politicians, most of whom, of course, are men.

I do not want to see the situation arise here in Australia which has arisen in New Zealand whereby a public appeal for funds has become necessary and has been undertaken. That appeal is using graphic pictures of battered women and crying children—victims of the domestic violence which the refuges seek to remove women and children from. The dignity of these women is one of the things that is so quickly lost. Victims of violence suffer in this area sufficiently without this kind of demeaning campaign being made necessary. That dignity is regained only through the sort of work that goes on in refuges and their associated services by the very women who visited me.

The kind of process that has been resorted to in New Zealand because of lack of funding and increased demand, because of the economic and social circumstances foisted on that country by economic rationalism, which we are suffering here as well, has extended that abuse by virtue of the use of these women and their children as part of that public appeal process. It is something that must not happen here. I appeal to my parliamentary colleagues—State and Federal—to acquaint themselves with the way that refuges work and with the processes and to understand their enormous value to our society and to the individual women and children concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter of the utmost importance to a number of my constituents in Tasmania. SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth agree that the operation of Benders Quarry within the Exit Cave areas nominated for World Heritage listing can continue provided that acceptable limits are set to the scale and development of the operation.
