I can assure you, officially and conclusively, that the Commonwealth does not object to your continued mining of limestone from the quarry in the Exit cave qualifying area.

PARA.TAB: However, four years later this official and conclusive assurance has been repudiated. A promise which seemed so secure has now been broken. So it makes one wonder whether one can trust anything that this Government actually states in its promises. One wonders why the reversal has happened. One suggestion has been that Mrs Kelly is pandering to the green vote with an election on the agenda. I will leave the readers of this debate to decide.

However, I would like to highlight one particular sentence which I have already stated. The Cook-Groom agreement provides that the quarry should continue within acceptable limits. That is the area I wish to emphasise:

SPEECH.PARA: Should any financial loss result from any limits placed on the operation, the Commonwealth would pay compensation direct to the company concerned.

The Commonwealth will ensure that the five workers at the quarry receive full redundancy entitlements and a fair ex gratia payment. We—
and I presume Mrs Kelly means the Government—
will explore ways in which former employees at Benders Quarry can be employed in rehabilitating the quarry.

You will note that I have just stated that there has been no mention of compensation to the owner of the quarry. The Government seems to think that he can suffer the loss. By the way, independent valuations have valued the compensation for the business to be as high as $4m.

PARA.TAB: To add insult to injury, the Government has stated that the five workers are to receive full redundancy entitlements, which all sounds very well when reported by the media throughout Australia. SPEECH.PARA: The Federal decision to close the quarry further undermined the security of resource supply for Tasmanian industry. . .

PARA.TAB: Therefore I feel it is urgent that this Government re-examine its decision of lack of compensation to date for the closure of this quarry. —Senator O'Chee, I remind you that you should address your remarks through the Chair, despite interjections.
—In spite of the rudeness of the other side, I will try to do so. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Early editions of yesterday's `Age' reported that a family company of the Prime Minister was an investor in Danpork Australia, which planned to import live pigs from Denmark as part of a joint-venture operation with a Danish company. This was incorrect.

PARA.TAB: The joint venture in which Mr Keating has an interest will use local stock. It has no intention of importing any pigs or breeding material from anywhere, and has not applied to do so. The mistake was made by a reporter.
Mr Keating says the joint venture has not been the subject of any ministerial talks, nor has it been involved in contact with the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service.

SPEECH.PARA: End of story. Where are the inaccuracies in this story? The inaccuracies in this story are multitudinous and I intend to address just some of them. First, the final comment in there was that this company has not been in contact with AQIS. That is quite simply not the case. The cablegram that I tabled in the Senate the other day makes it very clear that the reason why the review of the protocols regarding the importation of live pigs and genetic material had been made a priority issue was because of the Danish-Australian joint venture company in which Mr Keating had an interest. Danpork, of course, was the other half of the joint venture company. Incidentally, Danpork is tied up with the Federation of Danish Industries; Danpork is a consortium company made up of a number of Danish players in the pork industry.

PARA.TAB: It is very clearly the case, from the cablegram dated 7 July 1992, that it was that joint venture company—unless of course Senator Cook wishes to tell me about some other joint venture company between Danish interests and Australian interests—which was involved in the discussions with AQIS, and it is the one in which the Prime Minister has a substantial interest. Quite clearly, on the basis of that, either the Prime Minister has misled the newspaper or this cablegram is wrong, and the statements made in this chamber by Senator Button are wrong. And I would prefer to give Senator Button the benefit of the doubt.

The inference from this newspaper statement or rather the statement that the Prime Minister forced on the newspaper, in saying that the company is not intending to import any pigs or breeding material and has not applied to do so, is that it never intended to do so. That is quite clearly garbage. We have already seen from this cablegram that immense pressure was being placed on AQIS to review the protocols. In the answer that he gave to Senator Boswell on 17 June, Senator Button said:

SPEECH.PARA: This has led to the quarantine service telling the company that appropriate protocols would have to be developed if such imports were to take place. I understand that the Danpork company has now advised the quarantine service that it intends utilising the breeding qualities of Australian pigs, realising that it may not be appropriate to use its own stock.

It was only after we started raising this issue in the Senate and trying to make this Government accountable, and only after the political heat got too much, that Danpork and its joint venture partners—one of whom happens to indirectly be the Prime Minister—decided that they were not going to attempt to import any breeding material. It is technically correct, of course, that at no point did the joint venture make the application. But there were certainly numerous strong expressions of interest. There were numerous discussions between Danpork and AQIS that made it quite clear that that was its intention—to import the breeding material.

PARA.TAB: Again, Mr Keating has been making selective statements, bullying the press and trying to cover up this whole sorry saga. The bottom line is, irrespective of how selectively Mr Keating might make his statements and irrespective of how selectively Mr Keating might file his returns as a Minister of this Parliament, that it is clearly the case that there is an enormous stench about this which comes from one simple fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —You—it comes from you.

—That interjection from Senator Cook is his wittiest comment to date. Senator Cook is an interesting individual. As I understand it, they were going to name a street after him in his home State, but they could not find one narrow and twisted enough.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line is that there is a stench about this that arises solely out of the fact that we have a Prime Minister who is no longer capable of displaying the integrity which we expect of that high office. Either the Prime Minister misled the newspaper or Senator Button has misled the chamber, but I believe that Senator Button should be given the benefit of the doubt and that the Prime Minister should be made accountable.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I acknowledge that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), or his office, did send the corrections to me today. I want to make some general comments before speaking about some of the detail. The first comment I make, and I made it in the Estimates Committee last week, is that I have no intention of withdrawing anything. The question I asked then still stands. We dealt with some of that in the Estimates Committee and it revealed what has been happening in terms of this program.

PARA.TAB: I wish to recap a few points of it. I hope the Minister stays here because what he has done today is to table a paper to correct the mistakes that were made to the document he tabled in the Estimates Committee on 10 September, which was a document to correct the mistakes that were made to the document that was tabled on 20 August, to correct the mistakes that were made prior to my asking the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of them were made by me.
—I remember quite clearly a Premier, just recently, saying, `The buck stops with me' and resigning.
—None of them were made by me.

—It does not matter. Senator Cook has the responsibility for the administration of his Department. We have to follow this right through and it is important that we do follow it right through. When last I questioned the honourable senator on, I believe, 25 June, in the adjournment debate, he kept on shouting across the Chamber that I was a disgrace. That is recorded in Hansard. It happened because I asked a few questions about whether or not air tickets had been documented, whether or not proper accounts had been presented, whether the air fares that had been paid had been paid to the destination where the meeting was held.

PARA.TAB: I am going to go into that a little bit. I have a little story to tell here—a very interesting story. It is worth noting that even when we went to the Department—I was very appreciative of the opportunity to go there—we were able to point out some mistakes that should have been obvious to Blind Freddy. We pointed them out to the Department. But that was not all.

It required the calling in of Price Waterhouse because people within the Minister's responsibility could not add up. I am going to be generous and give them the benefit of the doubt, but when that original statement was put down here it was done in such a way as to make it appear that the Department owed the BLF money. In fact, what the Department did was to overclaim. As well as the other mistakes that were there, there was an overclaim on the moneys it called back from the WA branch of the BLF. That appeared in the press and elsewhere in association with the name of Senator Peter Cook, Minister for Industrial Relations. As I have said, I am going to give the departmental people the benefit of the doubt, taking it that they could not add up, but it makes me wonder.

Not only has it been revealed that they could not add up but also an air fare from Perth to Sydney is reimbursed when the meeting is held in Melbourne. An air fare from Perth to Sydney is reimbursed when the meeting is held in Canberra. I have the minutes here and I want to deal with them in a moment. They have been tabled here or before an Estimates committee. Those minutes state quite clearly that the claims were to be paid on the basis of economy air fares, not business class air fares. The Minister is now leaving the Chamber. That is worth noting. As one works through this sad and sorry episode and the incompetence that has occurred, one has to ask how far this extends into the operations of the Department of Industrial Relations.

If one looks a little bit further into this sad and sorry episode, one has to ask also why, under the building industry workplace reform program, when it came to paying all the other air fares, they were paid to the destination where the meetings were held and they were all paid on the basis of economy air fares. No mistakes there.

Then we look at the first minute, that of 13 February 1991. It states quite clearly that reimbursement is only for air fares. There is no written instruction—the Department could not deliver one at Estimates the other night—by which that was changed. Yet we find that accommodation was paid for until we get to 29 October 1991, and then we find in the minute of that date that it also includes accommodation costs in the case of Western Australian members.

We were told by the departmental officers on the night of the 10th that they thought that a verbal instruction was given. I presume that that came from the Minister. When we look at the situation which exists with WABAG and WATUAG—I will come back to my original question in a moment—we find that there are quite clear definite guidelines which spell out what will be paid and what will not be paid.

This poses another question: when dealing with his mates from the Western Australian BLF, how does Mr Reynolds, in particular, get preferential treatment, in terms of this building industry reform committee, quite different from what the others get?

Let us look a little further, because it is all very instructive and interesting, at where I got the basis for the original question. This highlights to me that somebody in the Minister's Department or in his office had had enough of what was going on, because on or about 14 June these documents from which I asked the question were left in my office. I believe they were deliberately left there because there was somebody in the Department or in his office who wanted to do the decent and honest thing and have what was going on exposed. The people who work in these departments and in his office are not stupid people; they would have recognised—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not dishonest, either.

—No, I do not believe they are dishonest, either. They would have recognised that airfares are not paid to Sydney when the meeting was held in Melbourne or Canberra, or business class airfares are not paid when the minute states absolutely clearly that they are economy fares. This is not an argument, as the Minister tried to elicit in the Estimates the other night, as to whether or not Western Australians, because of the distance they have to travel and the fact that they have to stay overnight, should have their accommodation paid. I would certainly support that proposition. The proposition that I put here is that, when a Minister delivers a minute to his Department, it is not only up to the Department to carry out that instruction, unless it is changed in writing, but it is also up to him to be aware of what is going on in terms of these things, particularly as I raised this question as far back as 25 June or thereabouts. So it throws up a whole host of additional questions.

PARA.TAB: I want to go to one other subject matter. These documents have been tabled, so I am not going to go through each of them one by one. We see, as was said at Estimates the other night, that in the final part of the minute—because the program was finished—the instructions were quite clearly that it would then be extended to accommodation for the Western Australian delegates. In fact, I should quote from it. This is the second minute I quote from, dated 29 October 1991. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The initial allocation of grant monies ($19,000) for payment of travel costs (and accommodation costs in the case of Western Australian members). . . —

I believe that the Minister will have to come back and make another correction to the statements he has put down, because even he should have been able to pick this one up: the accommodation costs have been paid for Mr Wayne Misdale. Mr Wayne Misdale, as I understand it, is contracted to the Department of Industrial Relations and operates out of Sydney. He was invited down here as a guest speaker. Under these minutes and the guidelines, why has Mr Wayne Misdale's accommodation been paid?

PARA.TAB: I believe that the Audit Office should go right through the Department of Industrial Relations and check all these particular accounts, because this looks like a very cosy, sweet little deal. We are not talking about an enormous amount of money, but we are talking about a principle. We are now talking about a position where the Western Australian BLF will have to be billed again to pay back the money that it has been overpaid. The Department should have been aware of that.

In the Estimates Committee the other night, when I asked why no guidelines had been given to the various delegates, as in WABAG and WATUAG, the answer was that they were told verbally what the arrangements were. So why are they claiming business class air fares when they have been briefed on what they are entitled to? Why is the Department paying—or overpaying, except in the case of Wayne Misdale—only the Western Australian branch of the Building Labourers Federation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is the Minister letting them do it?

—Indeed, why is the Minister letting them do it? I will come back to that point: I think the Audit Office should get into the Department of Industrial Relations and do a proper audit on the total operations of the Department. Let us find out how many more little quirks there are operating within that Department.

PARA.TAB: I now go back to my original question. The Minister said once again today that, if I were decent and honourable and did the right thing, I would withdraw the substance of that question. I have no intention whatsoever of withdrawing the substance of that question. The reasons are very clear.

First of all, I would be letting down the decency and the honesty of the person who had had enough of what was going on and moved to have it exposed. Secondly, this letter here, on reimbursement of travel of the WABLF, which is from Gary Quinlan to Mr Terry Brosnan and which was the substance of my question, says:

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken to the Minister about this. He is of the view that these are legitimate expenses under the WATUAG arrangements.

Yet we find that these expenses were not claimed by Mr Reynolds under those arrangements. They were claimed under the program of the building industry reform group, for work that was done in relation to that. Mr Reynolds knew that. That is why he claimed for them under that program.

PARA.TAB: Not only did the Minister know, his advisers advised him, in documents that have been tabled in the Senate, that there were some question marks about the legitimacy of those claims. Yet, instead of going back to Mr Reynolds and saying, `Hold on. These expenses are not legitimate', or, as he tried to claim here, that the money had run out—the money may well have run out; I am not disputing that—he sought to pay these expenses under another program. Mr Reynolds did not seek to do that. The Minister did it, in his discussions with Mr Gary Quinlan, as is borne out by what is in this letter. Far from my having to withdraw anything in this place, the reverse applies.

Senator Cook, the Minister, is going to have to come into the Senate yet again to explain why, under the guidelines in the minutes, Mr Wayne Misdale was paid. When he claims that we now have a full and proper record, there is only one reason we have the record to where it is at this point. I am not satisfied at this stage, any more than I was when we had the last adjournment debate on this, that we have seen the end of this.

I will wind up my comments on this by saying that it is indeed unfortunate that what has happened has happened. It is particularly unfortunate in view of the blight it has put on Western Australia. These things should not happen. Had there been proper administration, proper instruction from the Minister, clear guidelines, it would not have happened. As I said before the Minister left this chamber, the buck has to stop with him and not with anybody else. In this process of extracting teeth very slowly one must ask why, when it was pointed out, the Minister could not have come in and cleaned it up in one fell swoop. I do not believe, and I do not think anybodyelse in this place believes, that the people who work in the Department of Industrial Relations and in the Minister's office cannot add up.
